node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Is it okay to introduce a second language when neither parent is bilingual? Is it appropriative?

2. What’s the number one recommendation for encouraging a bilingual home (if you had to pick just one)?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Do I have to be fluent in a language to teach my child?

2. What if only one parent is bilingual?

3. It’s hard to have one-sided conversations in a language.

4. Will learning another language delay my child’s speech?

5. Will speaking 2 or 3 languages confuse or overwhelm my child?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Elina Furman is a Certified Infant Massage Instructor with over 15 years in the baby product industry. She is deeply passionate about spreading awareness about the importance of infant/child massage. She earned her certification after talking to many parents who were confused and bewildered about how to perform infant massage. 

By creating an educational platform and a massage enhancement tool, Elina hopes to bridge the gap of knowledge to help parents and underserved families explore this science evidence-based practice performed for thousands of years all over the world.
Follow her at @getkahlmi for more information and tips. 

In this IGTV, Elina answers:

1. What are the benefits of infant massage?

2. How to start and when to do it? How often? And until what age?

3. What if it seems like my baby doesn’t like massage?

4. Does infant massage help babies sleep better?

5. How do we continue with massage for older children?

6. Can massages relieve gas discomfort and can it be done before my baby gets to that point?

7. Are there any massages to help with teething?

#infantmassage #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. What age to worry about common mispronounced letters? (ex. R as W) Should my baby get evaluated professionally? 

2. How can I encourage my 3 year old to expand his short sentences?

3. Will mask-wearing by teachers affect the speech development of my 4 month old at daycare?

4. Does using a pacifier until at least 6 months of age affect speech?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Lauren Heffernan is a three-time Certified Pediatric Sleep Specialist with a focus on attachment. She is the owner of Isla-Grace Sleep (@islagracesleep) and the co-creator of the Baby-Led Sleep Approach.

Lauren is passionate about helping families to get more sleep without the use of any sleep training. Follow her at @islagracesleep for more advice and information.

In this episode, Lauren answers:

1. My 7 month old baby tosses and turns all night. She is restless. Should I be concerned?

2. Is there a biologically ideal bedtime for toddlers? What are your thoughts on bedsharing?

3. What do you think about dream feeds?

4. How long to keep a baby in a swaddle or Merlin suit? And how do I transition?

Be sure to watch all five ✋ IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Lauren's answers to the top questions on sleep. ✨

#sleep #babysleep #toddlersleep #expertadvice #sleepconsultant #attachmentparenting

node.text:
Lauren Heffernan is a three-time Certified Pediatric Sleep Specialist with a focus on attachment. She is the owner of Isla-Grace Sleep (@islagracesleep) and the co-creator of the Baby-Led Sleep Approach.

Lauren is passionate about helping families to get more sleep without the use of any sleep training. Follow her at @islagracesleep for more advice and information.

In this episode, Lauren answers:

1. Sleep tips for newborns?

2. When should we start sleep training?

Be sure to watch all five ✋ IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Lauren's answers to the top questions on sleep. ✨

#sleep #babysleep #toddlersleep #expertadvice #sleepconsultant #attachmentparenting

Parents are generally unaware of how ready young toddlers are to learn about numbers. We hear plenty about how important reading is for young children, but early introductions to math matter just as much. 👍

Neuroscientist, Gillian Starkey, says introducing your toddler to math can happen in the course of your regular day; it doesn’t have to require anything special. There are lots of easy ways to pay attention to the math and numbers that are all around us. The important thing is to use math as consciously as you use language so it becomes a regular, familiar part of your child’s day. ✨

A simple way to introduce math and numbers into your toddler’s day is by counting everything -- from toys, to fruit, even the steps from the car to your front door!

Counting helps familiarize your toddler with the concept that there are number words that go along with quantities. “I’m giving you four little crackers—one, two, three, four.” 🔢

Your toddler might start to do their own “counting” around two years old by reciting number words in order and pointing to objects in an attempt to mimic what you do when you count.

They are not yet making the connection between an actual quantity and the corresponding number word they are saying. Later, around age three or four, they will better understand what’s known as “one-to-one correspondence”—one ball goes with the number one, and two balls can be counted “one, two.”

We love this video from @Iniyaslearningjourney showing Iniya counting our Felt Flowers, a great example of a toddler reciting numbers and beginning to correspond them correctly. 🙌

#math #teachingmath #learningmath #toddlermath #learningnumbers #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlearning #toddlerlife

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 19, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Fact: Your toddler isn't giving you a hard time, they are going through a hard time. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
When your toddler is in the middle of a meltdown, it can be frustrating, emotionally exhausting, and well... basically any defeating emotion a human can possibly feel all at once. 🌪️

One thing to try and remember in those difficult moments is that your toddler is learning how to deal with all of these new emotions, while also figuring out how to communicate their needs and wants. And more importantly, they are truly just learning what this feeling FEELS like. That's A LOT for their little bodies to handle. 🙃 Even as adults, it’s hard to communicate what you need when you are filled with rage, right?

Instead of putting adult-level expectations onto our little children, it can be helpful to remember that these are all new experiences and very complex emotions for them. These kids of ours, who want to hear the ABCs over and over again and trying to learn the colors of the rainbow, are not quite experts in managing emotions. 🌈

Your toddler isn't purposefully giving you a hard time, but rather they are going through a hard time. ❤️

Tantrums are never, ever easy, but you and your toddler will get through them together. 🥰

#tantrums #tantrumtips #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlife #toddlers #lovevery

node.text:
Sensory play, science, fine motor, and FUN! 🥳 Water play checks all the boxes. ✅

The Drip Drop Cups from the Inspector Play Kit for 7-8 months are the perfect water play essentials. This is also great way to help your little one cool down on those warm summer days. ☀️

Show your child how water drips from the cups as you lift them, they will find this new way to play with water so fascinating. 💦

We love this video from @mydomesticden, keep tagging us in all your summer adventures! ☀️

REMINDER: Never leave your child alone near water. Children can drown in as little as two inches of water, so constant supervision is critical.

#waterplay #sensoryplay #watertoys #learningthroughplay #toddleractivities #babyactivities #playtolearn #summerfun #lovevery

node.text:
So much learning and even more fun is packed into the Tummy Time Wobbler. The Wobbler moves on its own, and capturing a moving toy is hard but exciting work! ⁣⁣🤩
⁣⁣
First your baby’s eyes need to track the moving object 👀, then their brain has to plan how they're going to get it 🧠, finally they have to anticipate when they're going to grab it 👊. They also need plenty of neck, back, and shoulder strength to reach and get it. 💪
⁣⁣
Wow... aren't you exhausted just reading all of that?! 😅 It's a tough workout for their brain and body.⁣

We love this video from @syuzyhovhannisyan of their little one Narek using the Wobbler during tummy time and rocking it! 💪

#tummytime #tummytimewobbler #babydevelopment #babymilestones #sustainabletoys #learningthroughplay #playtolearn #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on July 15, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Fact: Your toddler is growing every day- physically, mentally, and emotionally. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
Your toddler is constantly changing, growing, evolving, and learning. If you sometimes struggle to keep up with all the change, you’re not alone. 💕

We gathered together five facts to help you better understand your toddler: 👇

🧠 Your toddler’s brain is working twice as hard as yours:
“Before preschoolers enter kindergarten, their brains are more active and more flexible, with more connections per brain cell than the brains of adult human beings,” says Alison Gopnik, a leading cognitive psychologist at University of California, Berkeley. In other words, your toddler is processing a lot. Try to keep this in mind and give them (and yourself) a break next time they express big emotions in the form of a meltdown, tantrum, or power struggle.

🤩 Giving independence to toddlers early on can lead to fewer power struggles later:
When you grant your toddler independence, they develop confidence and a greater sense of self. As early as 14 months, try offering them responsibilities and chores to help them feel valuable and like they have a place and purpose in the home.

✨ Toddlers have a universal desire to help without the expectation of getting something for it:
Before you offer your toddler a reward for their help, consider this: studies have shown that being rewarded for an act changes children’s attitudes towards the act, and discourages them from wanting to do it again on their own. A simple “thank you” or positive words of encouragement can be enough acknowledgement.

🙌 Routines provide comfort, stability, and a sense of safety for your toddler:
Patterns in your toddler’s day are comforting because they help them understand and prepare for what’s going to happen next.

😂 When toddlers know they can make people laugh, it builds their self-esteem:
According to Dr. Mary L. Gavin of KidsHealth, “kids with a well-developed sense of humor are happier and more optimistic, have higher self-esteem, and can handle differences (their own and others’) well.”

#toddlerlife #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlearning #toddlerparent #toddlertips #lovevery

Photo by Lovevery on July 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Fact: Babies figure out the grammar of their primary language even before they learn to speak. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
Your baby intuitively knows that “Mama/Dada loves coffee their” is wrong and “Mama/Dada loves their coffee” is right. 😮

Before they are able to use it, eight-month-old babies figure out the grammar of their primary language. 👏

A study from the Integrative Neuroscience and Cognition Center found that eight-month-old babies can tell the difference between functors (frequently used support words like articles, pronouns, and prepositions) and content words (words used in specific context like nouns, verbs, and adjectives). According to the study, babies understand where functors are placed in relation to content words. 🧠

Babies typically learn to say content words first (like “Mama” or "Dada" ❤️) but this study demonstrates that they understand support words much earlier. This means that they focus, in part, on the structure of language when they are learning a new one.

"Children...are in fact much more flexible and can easily learn a language that has a different word order from their own, while adults seem to be more rigidly tied to their native language scheme,” says Marina Nespor, a researcher from the Integrative Neuroscience and Cognition Center. 🙌

Our children are so amazing! 🤓🥳

#languagedevelopment #toddlerspeech #speechandlanguagedevelopment #toddlercommunication #lovevery

node.text:
Kicking play encourages so much physical and mental development in your baby. 🙌

When your baby kicks, they are starting to understand that their body can create noise and movement. They are building important neck strength by tucking their chin to look down at their legs and feet -- this “chin tuck” helps build strength for rolling over from back to side, and then eventually from back to belly. They are also growing their core strength that will help them sit up in the coming months. There is SO much going on developmentally in such a simple movement. 

One way to encourage kicking play is through the Jingle Socks from the Senser Play Kit for 5-6 months. These playful socks make noise as your baby kicks and show them the cause and effect -- when they move their feet and legs, a pleasant sound is made! ✨

These fun socks will make your baby go on a kicking craze, just like in this video from @elainershayes. 💕

#babydevelopment #physicaldevelopment #braindevelopment #babyactivities #babylearning #learningthroughplay #playtolearn #lovevery

node.text:
Finding calm and connection when your toddler is in crisis mode can feel impossible. But connecting with your child is actually the best thing you can do to help de-escalate these BIG emotions. 🙃

Your toddler’s brain is working twice as hard as yours -- they are processing a lot. Try to keep this in mind and give them (and yourself) a break next time they express big emotions in the form of a meltdown, tantrum, or power struggle -- they aren’t seeking attention, they are trying to communicate and connect with you. 💕

#tantrumtips #toddlerlife #toddlertantrums #jodycarrington #toddlerdevelopment #peacefulparenting #lovevery

node.text:
Babies crave a lot of exposure to different sights, sounds, and textures. Tummy time is a great way to incorporate sensory stimulation for your baby! 🙌

We spent A LOT of time on Pinterest looking for tummy time inspiration -- here are some of our favorites. 👇

💦 Float the Wobbler from the Senser Play Kit or some balls on a sheet tray with water. 

🌱 Put some fresh herbs on a baking sheet with your baby propped up on a pillow. 

❄️ Fill a sturdy sealable bag with ice, and tape it to the floor.

🍝 Put some dried pasta or beans on a tray.

Tag us if you try any of these fun tummy time activities! 

#tummytime #tummytimeideas #babydevelopment #babyideas #babyactivities #lovevery
